meanings.definition: The maximum safe engine speed at which an internal combustion engine can operate without causing damage.
meanings.sent1: When the car's engine reached the redline, it was running at its fastest speed.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic warned not to push the engine past the redline to avoid any harm.
meanings.sent3: The race car driver joked that he could hear the redline calling his name as he accelerated.
meanings.sent4: The redline of the engine was like a barrier, protecting it from going too fast and breaking down.
meanings.sent5: The redline on the tachometer was a clear indicator of when to shift gears for optimal performance.

meanings.definition: To mark or highlight something in red.
meanings.sent1: She used a red pen to redline the important sections of the document.
meanings.sent2: The teacher asked the students to redline any errors in their essays.
meanings.sent3: The artist decided to redline the outline of the painting to make it stand out more.
meanings.sent4: The editor's job was to redline the errors in the manuscript before it went to print.
meanings.sent5: He carefully redlined the key points in the presentation to ensure they were noticed by the audience.

meanings.definition: To set a limit or boundary that should not be crossed.
meanings.sent1: The coach had to redline the rules to prevent any cheating during the game.
meanings.sent2: It's important to redline your spending to stay within your budget.
meanings.sent3: The teacher had to redline the time for the test to ensure fairness for all students.
meanings.sent4: The company decided to redline the number of attendees for safety reasons.
meanings.sent5: The government had to redline the speed limit to maintain road safety for everyone.
